awd_titl_txt: PIRE: Crafting Optimal Learning in Science Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
The PIRE award aims to enhance secondary science teachers' skills in promoting engaging activities in classrooms. Recently, both the United States and Finland have developed new science standards that stress the value of instructional activities that are interesting, challenging, and relevant to students? lives and futures. Of particular interest are the classroom messages and instructional tasks in classrooms that have discouraged women, underrepresented minorities, and individuals with special needs from pursuing careers in STEM fields. This project is a collaboration between researchers and teachers in the United States and Finland that: 1) measures the academic, social, and emotional learning of students in secondary science classes; 2) investigates the effect of the implementation of a new form of science instruction modeled after the new Next Generation Science Standards; and 3) creates an integrated exchange program between the United States and Finland for students, teachers, teacher educators, researchers, and policy leaders to foster the professional development of science teachers and improvement of teacher education programs. The planned educational exchange program will involve teams of U.S. teacher educators, science teachers, and science teacher interns traveling to Finland in order to exchange research findings and teaching expertise with their Finnish counterparts. It is anticipated that these exchanges will expand participants? networks providing them more sources of information to elevate the professionalism of teachers and deepen their STEM knowledge. 

To capitalize on science activities in secondary chemistry and physics classrooms in the United States and Finland that have been shown through prior research to enhance engagement and learning, the project will create an instructional intervention which advances reforms in science education, specifically project based learning, and compares it with conventional science instructional techniques. Using both innovative single case study design and smartphone technology this research will test when students participate in the instructional intervention do they experience an increase in science relevance both for themselves and society and science learning? Working with teachers, four science units will be created and replicated over a three year period (with additional new schools, teachers, and students in each successive year). By the end of year three a larger field test will be conducted in which the intervention will be implemented in 40 classrooms in twenty treatment high schools affecting nearly 2,000 students representing diverse backgrounds (with matched control populations). The conduct of this work, from its design to implementation, will be jointly undertaken in Finnish schools with similarly aged students. 

This award is cofunded by the Division of Research on Learning, Directorate for Education and Human Resources.

por.por_cntn:
Crafting Engaging Science Environments (CESE) is an innovative science intervention for chemistry and physics high school students, created in collaboration with colleagues in Finland, that has been piloted, field-tested, and most recently rigorously tested in two US states. Drawing a sample of several thousand diverse students who were balanced between treatment and control conditions; results showed that students who received the science intervention outperformed their counterparts on a state standardized science test and showed an increase in future four-year college enrollment.

The CESE intervention was specifically designed to assist all students in succeeding in advanced science courses that often serve as gatekeepers, posing barriers to college admission especially for schools that serve predominately low-income and underrepresented minorities. Created to advance a new vision of science teaching and learning, CESE consists of evidence-based specified educational teacher and student materials including technologically challenging modeling activities, end-of-unit assessments, and professional learning supports. Focusing on what students should know and be able to do similar to the practices of scientists and engineers; CESE was designed based upon the principles of project-based learning which invites students to become scientists, engineers, and problem-solvers who ask deep questions and lead meaningful inquiry both in and out of the classroom.

CESE also brings together three dimensions of science knowledge: crosscutting concepts across science disciplines, concrete science and engineering practices, and disciplinary core ideas with curricular materials and professional learning experiences that encourage educators to enact meaningful science instruction in their secondary science classrooms. One of the few interventions that aligns with the performance expectations recommended in the Next Generation Science Standards, CESE is designed to serve all high school students, not just those in advanced placement or honors programs, by supporting social and emotional learning and enhancing instruction with meaningful and challenging science experiences. (See Improving Science Achievement—Is It Possible? Educational Researcher, DOI:10.3102/0013189X211067742. And The Value of Crafting Engagement in Science Environments, Yale University Press.)

The CESE curriculum will continue beyond the grant period. Recently, the project has received a multi-million-dollar Education Innovation and Research Grant from the U.S. Department of Education to develop the curriculum to be more culturally responsive and meet the needs of secondary science students and educators in the rural South. In collaboration between Michigan State University and two Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) Alabama A&M University and Winston Salem State University, the CESE curriculum will be further developed and evaluated to make it more culturally responsive and applicable to the lives and needs of traditionally underserved students. Through this work to enhance the CESE curriculum, more students will experience engaging, innovative science instruction which encourages them to sustain an interest in STEM and pursue higher education and careers in science fields.
